Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research goal of this project is to elucidate the mechanics and magneto-mechanics of magnetic shape-memory alloys at the nanoscale, and to explore the potential and limitations of magnetic shape-memory alloys in small-scale devices. Four objectives include: (i) Mechanics and magneto-mechanics of nano-columns; (ii) Structure, phase transformation, and mechanics of thin films; (iii) Fabrication and magneto-mechanics of nanodiscs and nanowires; (iv) Interaction of magnetic domains and crystallographic twins on the nano-scale. The combined study of nanofabrication, processing and thermo-magneto-nanomechanical characterization will link microstructural features to unique properties spawned by their reduced size. Nanofabrication and processing techniques will include physical vapor deposition of films on various substrates, electron-beam lithography, focused-ion-beam machining and thermo-magneto-mechanical training. The microstructure and magnetic domain structure will be characterized with various scanning probe techniques and transmission electron microscopy techniques.

Current device, logical and memory technology is based on binary mono-functional elements and volatile device states. The multi-state, multifunctional and non-volatile magnetic shape-memory alloy nanostructures bear a high potential to open new pathways for small-scale devices and memory applications. Students employed through this project will engage in an international effort, which includes visits at partner institutions in Austria and Spain. Following a successful tradition at Boise State University, several undergraduate students will be included in research efforts. They will present results at international conferences and author peer-reviewed journal articles. Outreach activities are targeted towards grade schools to attract children to careers in science and technology and include regular visits of grade school classrooms.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
We study magnetic shape memory materials (MSMAs) with an emphasis on its magneto-mechanical properties, i.e. their mechanical response to a magnetic stimulus. Since we are describing a scientific phenomenon you do not see in today’s technologies, it may help to use familiar science fiction to explain what it is and how it works. In the movie Terminator 2 (1991), Arnold Schwarzenegger starred as the hero, the T-800 robot sent back from the future to save the world. Although sophisticated by our standards, Schwarzenegger’s robot was built out of numerous interlinking electro-mechanical parts. His nemesis, however, was a more advanced T?1000 robot, fabricated from a single material. Its “liquid metal” structure allowed it to fluidly morph into new shapes, recover, and control the operation: in this innovative engineering paradigm, the material is the machine. MSMAs are similar in concept to the “liquid metal” robot. Although not humanoid, MSMA does shape-shift, here in response to magnetic fields. Apply a magnetic field, and the material changes shape. Remove it, and the new shape remains. Apply a different magnetic field and the material re-forms into a new shape. Do this quickly and with purpose, and you have a machine.

The MSMA material machine is strikingly simple. All you need is to combine a MSMA element (e.g. a beam or rod) with a suitably designed set of copper coils and control electronics. There are no moving parts. Besides the simplicity of design, the MSMA material machine works frictionless.  This makes MSMA devices highly suitable for miniaturization since friction limits conventional mechanical machines at small scale. MSMAs find use in micro-actuators such as micro-pumps and switches.

In this project, we developed methods for fabricating small-scale MSMA objects and structures such as thin films and dots. We developed a sputtering method with which we can systematically vary the composition of the films. This is important because small changes in composition strongly affect the properties of MSMAs. With this method, we produced a series of Ni-Mn-Ga thin films. We then characterized these films for homogeneity, composition, structure (i.e. the arrangement of atoms), phase transformations (MSMAs undergo changes similar to the freezing of water to ice), and stresses. We demonstrated thin films with similar properties as Ni-Mn-Ga bulk material.

We also developed a method using MSMA for storing data. Here, we indented a highly polished surface of a Ni-Mn-Ga single crystal with an extremely pointed diamond tip. In this way, we produced very small triangular dimples with edge length between 15 and 60 nm. These dimples generated a magnetic stray field that we recorded with an equally small magnetic probe. Each dimple created a small, directional black/white signature. We then squeezed the Ni-Mn-Ga crystal which caused a small deformation. This deformation rotated the directional black/white signature by 90 degrees. We demonstrated switching in all four directions, ie. each dimple constituted a bit with four states. Thus, each dimple carried twice as much information as a conventional bit on a chip.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2015
Modified by: Peter Mullner
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We study magnetic shape memory materials (MSMAs) with an emphasis on its magneto-mechanical properties, i.e. their mechanical response to a magnetic stimulus. Since we are describing a scientific phenomenon you do not see in todayÆs technologies, it may help to use familiar science fiction to explain what it is and how it works. In the movie Terminator 2 (1991), Arnold Schwarzenegger starred as the hero, the T-800 robot sent back from the future to save the world. Although sophisticated by our standards, SchwarzeneggerÆs robot was built out of numerous interlinking electro-mechanical parts. His nemesis, however, was a more advanced T?1000 robot, fabricated from a single material. Its "liquid metal" structure allowed it to fluidly morph into new shapes, recover, and control the operation: in this innovative engineering paradigm, the material is the machine. MSMAs are similar in concept to the "liquid metal" robot. Although not humanoid, MSMA does shape-shift, here in response to magnetic fields. Apply a magnetic field, and the material changes shape. Remove it, and the new shape remains. Apply a different magnetic field and the material re-forms into a new shape. Do this quickly and with purpose, and you have a machine. The MSMA material machine is strikingly simple. All you need is to combine a MSMA element (e.g. a beam or rod) with a suitably designed set of copper coils and control electronics. There are no moving parts. Besides the simplicity of design, the MSMA material machine works frictionless. This makes MSMA devices highly suitable for miniaturization since friction limits conventional mechanical machines at small scale. MSMAs find use in micro-actuators such as micro-pumps and switches. In this project, we developed methods for fabricating small-scale MSMA objects and structures such as thin films and dots. We developed a sputtering method with which we can systematically vary the composition of the films. This is important because small changes in composition strongly affect the properties of MSMAs. With this method, we produced a series of Ni-Mn-Ga thin films. We then characterized these films for homogeneity, composition, structure (i.e. the arrangement of atoms), phase transformations (MSMAs undergo changes similar to the freezing of water to ice), and stresses. We demonstrated thin films with similar properties as Ni-Mn-Ga bulk material. We also developed a method using MSMA for storing data. Here, we indented a highly polished surface of a Ni-Mn-Ga single crystal with an extremely pointed diamond tip. In this way, we produced very small triangular dimples with edge length between 15 and 60 nm. These dimples generated a magnetic stray field that we recorded with an equally small magnetic probe. Each dimple created a small, directional black/white signature. We then squeezed the Ni-Mn-Ga crystal which caused a small deformation. This deformation rotated the directional black/white signature by 90 degrees. We demonstrated switching in all four directions, ie. each dimple constituted a bit with four states. Thus, each dimple carried twice as much information as a conventional bit on a chip. Last Modified: 11/22/2015 Submitted by: Peter Mullner
